TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY AT A GLANCE

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) facility for Unlocking the Potential for Climate 
Change- and Disaster-Resilient Multisector Provincial Projects will (i) provide project preparation 
support,  including  due diligence  assessment, for two  ensuing  projects, (ii)  prepare  climate 
adaptation  solutions for another two ensuing projects,1 and (iii) support project preparation 
capacity building for provincial governments, including in the area of climate and disaster risks 
and various adaptation pathways. The TA facility is listed in the country operations business plan 
for Viet Nam, 2021–2023.2  
 
2.  Necessary  shift  from  multi-province  single  sector  approach  to  single  province 
multisector solutions. Regulatory reforms in public investment and debt management in Viet 
Nam have increased responsibilities of the provincial governments for managing and using official 
development  assistance  (ODA)  and  concessional  loans. 3  With  these  reforms,  provincial 
governments can no longer from benefit from “umbrella projects” in which a line ministry manages 
a multi-province single sector project, and participating provinces are subsidiaries that are fully 
dependent, administratively and financially, on the ministry. Instead, each province is delegated 
to prepare, implement, and be accountable for investment projects for its local socioeconomic 
development. Following the central government’s guidance to prepare the national midterm public 
investment plan for 2021–2025, provinces are requested to individually prepare province-based 
multisector projects for increased synergy, efficiency, and impact of provincial public investments. 
Since 2020, ADB has received requests from several provinces for sovereign financing for single 
province multisector projects. Further, the need for a shift from a multi-province single sector 
approach to single-province multisector solutions is evident from ADB’s operations experience in 
Viet Nam. Multi-province projects tend to experience delays in project processing because the 
different levels of readiness among provinces mean some provinces must wait for others to obtain the 
same level of readiness. Differing capacity of participating provinces have exacerbated such delays.4 
     
3.  The single-province multisector project approach requires a shift in project team 
composition. Provincial multisector projects proposed by individual provinces are relatively small in 
scope and less complex in technical solutions and safeguards issues, and thus extensive international 
expertise to support project design is not expected. Projects that cover multiple sectors at the 
provincial level raise the issue of which sector division would lead the processing when each 
respective sector is only a part of the project. These projects require  intensive and constant 
coordination  among  different  ADB  sector  teams  and  between  ADB  and  the  relevant  local 
governments,  which  often  have  significant  constraints  in  communicating  in  foreign  languages. 
Moreover, in the context of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, international travel 
restrictions may constrain inputs from ADB staff and consultants based outside of Viet Nam, affecting 
project readiness and processing schedules. To effectively and efficiently coordinate collaborative 
work among  sector  divisions on crosscutting  development  issues  and integrated solutions for 
multisector projects, it is deemed prudent to assign processing of single-province multisector projects 
 
1 List of Projects for Transaction Technical Assistance Facility Support (accessible from the list of linked documents in 
Appendix 3). These projects are in Binh Phuoc, Hoa Binh, Nam Dinh and Tay Ninh provinces. These projects have 
been proposed by relevant provincial people’s committees for the Prime Minister’s approval.  
2 ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Viet Nam, 2021–2023. Manila. The former title of this TA in the country 
operations business plan, 2021–2023 was the Integrated Provincial Infrastructure Facility.   
3Such regulatory reforms include the Public Investment Law, 2019 (effective from January 2020) and Decree 
56/2020/ND-CP on the management and use of official development assistance and concessional loans (effective 
from May 2020).    
4 ADB. 2020. Viet Nam: Country Partnership Strategy Final Review, 2016–2019. Manila; and ADB. 2021. Viet Nam: 
Validation of the Country Partnership Strategy Final Review, 2016–2020. Manila.

2   
   
   
to the Viet Nam Resident Mission (VRM). This arrangement will also help pursue a higher quality of 
engagement with local governments and maintain ADB’s responsiveness in Viet Nam, especially in 
cases of future disruptions like the COVID-19 pandemic.5 Single-province multisector projects can be 
effectively processed by the VRM, where its international staff and/or national officers have adequate 
capacity to lead project processing, with (i) outposted sector staff as co-lead and/or mentor, (ii) 
specialized expertise and quality control provided by ADB headquarters staff, and (iii) respective 
sector directors’ oversight. The VRM is prepared to deploy VRM in-house capacity for project 
processing,  including  procurement,  safeguards,  economic  and  financial  analysis  and  financial 
management due diligence as required, and explore opportunities to mobilize locally-based qualified 
international and national consultants to reduce the risks of project processing delays from possible 
continued disruptions from the COVID-19 pandemic and associated project processing costs. 
 
4.  Need for support to provincial governments to identify climate adaptation  solutions. 
Viet Nam is one of the most climate vulnerable countries in the world, highly exposed to multiple 
climate-related hazards such as floods, typhoons, and droughts.6 There are urgent needs to scale 
up  climate  change  and  disaster  resilient  investments  to  help  steer  economic  growth.  The 
government has put in place robust legislation, strategies, and plans, including the National 
Strategy on Natural Disaster Prevention, Control, and Mitigation to 2020; the National Strategy 
on Climate Change; and the National Climate Change Adaptation Plan.7 These directions are in 
line with ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priority of tackling climate change, building climate and 
disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability.8 National policies require all 
provinces to develop their respective plans and associated investments, making it critical to 
support  provincial  governments  in  strengthening  their  climate  change  and  disaster  risk 
management plans, and more importantly, designing investment projects that help strengthen 
provincial resilience with feasible adaptation  solutions.  
 
5.  Need  for  expertise  and  capacity  development  in  preparing  projects.  While 
responsibilities in mobilizing and managing ODA and concessional resources for provincial 
socioeconomic development have been strongly decentralized to provinces, most provincial 
governments have limited capacity to prepare projects that meet the requirements for financing 
by external development partners, including ADB. Provincial investment feasibility studies often 
lack, among others, technical viability assessment with technological innovations and green 
solutions; financial and economic analysis; environmental impact examinations; social impacts 
assessment on resettlement, gender, poverty reduction, and disadvantaged groups of people, 
including  ethnic  minorities;  climate  and  disaster  risk  analysis;  and  institutional  capacity 
assessment  in  procurement,  financial  management,  and  project  management.  In  addition, 
government regulations  on  processing ODA  and  concessional  loan-funded  projects  do  not 
provide detailed guidelines on preparing project documents and submission checklists, causing 
confusion  and  misunderstanding  among  project  proposing  agencies  and  delays  in  project 
appraisal and approval processes. Provincial governments’ limited capacity in complying with 
both ADB and government project processing requirements has significantly prolonged the 
processing schedules of ADB-funded projects.  
 
 
5  ADB. 2020. Review of ADB’s Resident Mission Operations. Manila. 
6  Government of Viet Nam. 2015. Intended Nationally Determined Contribution of Viet Nam. Ha Noi.  
7  The National Strategy on Natural Disaster Prevention, Control, and Mitigation to 2020 was issued by Viet Nam Prime 
Minister in Decision 172/2007/QD-TTg dated 16 November 2007; the National Strategy on Climate Change was 
issued in Decision 2139/QD-TTg dated 05 December 2011; the National Climate Change Adaptation Plan for the 
period 2021-2030, with a vision to 2050, was issued in Decision 1055/QD-TTg dated 20 July 2020. 
8  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

3 
 
6.  Rationale for a national transaction technical assistance facility. The national TA 
facility approach is suitable for Viet Nam because it will support various provinces to identify 
potential single-province multisector projects and design specific projects for potential ADB 
financing.  The  TA  packages  for  each  of  these  provinces  are  expected  to  have  similar 
implementation arrangements: The TA facility approach, therefore, will enhance the efficiency 
and effectiveness of ADB resources by mobilizing the same consultants to address common 
issues faced across provinces. Using a common pool of consultants will also create synergies 
and thus foster knowledge sharing and transfer across provinces. Finally, the TA facility approach 
will reduce transaction costs compared to separate, stand-alone transaction TA projects for 
individual provinces, especially in the context of Viet Nam where government procedures for 
processing a transaction TA are particularly complex and lengthy.9  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Due diligence assessments for ensuing projects prepared. The TA facility 
will prioritize support to two single-province multi-sector projects (footnote 1). The TA facility will 
provide consultants to support due diligence assessments for these two investment projects for 
potential ADB financing, including  the assessment of technical viability and suitability of the 
proposed solutions, economic and financial viability and sustainability, governance associated with 
institutional capacity (e.g., financial management, procurement, and policy), environmental and 
social safeguards, climate risk and adaptation assessment, and disaster risk assessment. The TA 
facility will also identify risks and take risk-mitigating measures to further strengthen the project 
implementation capacity of the executing and implementing agencies for the ensuing investment 
projects. Activities will include, as required: (i) economic analysis; (ii) financial analysis and financial 
management  capacity  assessment;  (iii)  strategic  procurement  planning  and  procurement 
management capacity assessment; (iv) risk assessment and management plans; (v) safeguards 
due diligence on environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples; (vi) climate 
change assessment; (vii) gender analysis, including labor-related analysis and action plan; and (viii) 
poverty and social analysis, including labor-related analysis and strategy. 
 
8.   Output 2: Climate adaptation solutions for ensuing projects identified. The TA 
facility will help strengthen the design of two selected provincial projects (footnote 1) to build 
provincial  climate  and  disaster  resilience  in line with provincial priorities identified in their 
respective climate change adaptation and/or disaster risk management plans. The TA facility will 
provide consultants to undertake provincial climate and disaster risk assessments to identify 
adaptation  pathways,  prioritize  multisectoral  climate  change  adaptation  and  disaster  risk 
reduction interventions for strengthening resilience, and propose adaptation solutions including 
both structural solutions (green, grey, and hybrid infrastructure) and non-structural support 
measures.  The TA facility will also provide selected government officials with necessary training 
on climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction, especially to share knowledge on 
novel resilience measures, such as nature-based solutions.     
 
9.  Output 3: Provincial capacity in preparing ensuing projects improved. The TA facility 
will provide training workshops on project preparation skills and project processing procedures 
for  ODA  and  concessional  loan-funded  projects,  following  aligned  government  and  ADB 
standards and business processes (footnote 10), for the selected provinces with ensuing projects 
potentially funded by ADB (footnote 1). Project preparation skills will focus on participatory 
consultation  approaches,  financial  and  economic  analysis,  strategic  procurement  planning, 
safeguard  and  labor  issue  screening,  institutional  capacity  assessment,  climate  change 
 
9 Pursuant to Decree 56/2020/ND-CP on the management and use of ODA and concessional loans, the processing of 
a transaction technical assistance project requires two submissions to the Prime Minister for approval.

4   
   
   
assessment, poverty and social analysis, and gender analysis, among others. The training on 
project processing procedures will primarily target the government’s detailed business processes 
and specific requirements for government approval of project proposals, project investment policy 
report, and project feasibility study. Targeted trainees may include provincial government officials 
(and provincial consultants) who would be directly involved in appraising and processing potential 
ADB-funded projects. International and/or national experts and staff with relevant technical 
expertise from ADB and central government agencies, including the Ministry of Planning and 
Investment, Ministry of Finance, and State Bank of Viet Nam, will be invited to be resource 
persons for these training programs. Modalities of training and workshops will depend on the 
COVID-19 pandemic situation. If a face-to-face modality is not feasible, virtual media will be used. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1,500,000, of which (i) $1,000,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources)  and  (ii) 
$500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund.10 The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1. The TA facility will be replenished from time to time as funds are 
required and as additional projects are identified. 
 
11.  The  government  will  provide  in-kind  contributions  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff, 
counterpart staff’s travel costs for TA facility-related work, access to existing reports and data, 
and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA facility does 
not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA facility and will administer and implement the 
TA  facility  through  the  VRM  of  the  Southeast  Asia  Department  in  coordination  with  the 
department’s sector divisions and other relevant departments.11  
13.  Activities under output 1 will start only after (i) the government approves the project proposal 
for the ensuing project or ADB reaches an agreement with the relevant provincial government to 
commence the activities and (ii) ADB approves the project concept paper of the ensuing project. 
Consulting services for each ensuing project will start only after an agreement with the respective 
provincial  government  on  the  scope  of  assignments,  terms  of  reference  for  consultants, 
implementation arrangements, and schedules, among other things, have been confirmed.  
14.  The scope of the TA facility is expected to be expanded to support additional projects and 
provinces as identified during ADB’s upcoming country programming missions. The TA facility 
implementation period is 5 years from the date of TA facility effectiveness.

16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.12 Consultants will 
be engaged through two selection methods: quality- and cost-based selection (QCBS) (90:10) and 
individual consultant selection. The QCBS packages will provide consulting for project preparation 
support (output 1) and will be procured in two steps. First, five to seven consulting firms will be 
selected as prequalified consultants that are eligible to submit proposals for the preparation of all 
ensuing projects under the TA facility. Second, once a project concept is approved, relevant 
shortlisted consultants will be invited to submit proposals to prepare that project following QCBS 
procedure. Individual consultants to implement certain activities under output 1 and all activities 
under output 2, and resource persons to support training activities under output 3 will be engaged 
following the individual consultant selection method.   
 
E.  Governance  
 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency, and thus the financial management, procurement, and 
integrity risks during the TA facility implementation are assessed to be low. However, the TA facility 
will conduct thorough risk assessments of these governance areas for ensuing investment projects.  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Unlocking the Potential for Climate Change- and Disaster-
Resilient Multisector Provincial Projects, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
